note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: WHat happiness waits on the life at Court,
What dear content, greatness, delight & ease?
What ever-springing hopes, what tides of honour,
That raise their fortunes to the height of wishes?
What can be more in man, what more in nature,
Then to be great and fear'd? A Courtier,
A noble Courtier, 'Tis a name that drawes
Wonder, and dutie, from all eyes and knees.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And so your Worships land within the walls,
Where you shall have it all inclos'd and sure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Peace knave; dull creature, bred of sweate and smoke,
These mysteries are far above thy faith:
But thou shalt seeâ€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And then I shall believe;
Your faire revenues, turn'd into faire suites,
I shall believe your Tenants bruis'd and rent
Under the weight of Coaches, all your state
Drawn through the streets in triumph, suits for places
Plied with a mine of gold, and being got
Fed with a great streame, I shall believe all this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You shall believe, and know me glorious.
Cozin good day and health. Enter Cozen.

sp.speaker: Couzen.
sp.l: The same to you Sir,
And more, without my wishes, could you know
What calm content dwels in a private house:
Yet looke into your selfe, retire: this place
Of promises, and protestations, fits
Minds only bent to ruine, you should know this,
You have their language perfect, you have tutors
I doe not doubt sufficient: but beware.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are merry Couzin:

sp.speaker: Cozen.
sp.l: Yet your patience,
You shall learn that too, but not like it selfe
Where it is held a vertue; tell me Sir,
Have you cast up your state, rated your land,
And finde it able to endure the change
Of time and fashion? is it alwayes harvest?
Alwayes vintage? have you ships at Sea
To bring you gold, and stone from rich Peru
Monthly returning treasure? doth the King
Open his large Exchequer to your hands
And bid you be a great man? can your wife
Coyne off her beauty? or the weeke allow
Suites to each day? and know no ebb in honour?
If these be possible, and can hold out,
Then be a Courtier still, and still be wasting,

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Cozen, pray give me leave:

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I could requite your gall, and in a straine
As bitter, and as full of Rubarb, preacht
Against your Countrey life, but 'tis below me
And only subject to my pitty, know
The eminent court, to them that can be wise,
And fasten on her blessings, is a sunne
That drawes men up from course and earthly being,
I meane these men of merit that have power
And reason to make good her benefits,
Learns them a manly boldnesse, gives their tongues
Sweetnesse of language, makes them apt to please;
Files of all rudenesse, and uncivill haviour,
Shews them as neat in carriage as in cloaths;
Cozen have you ever seen the Court?

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: No Sir,
Nor am I yet in travaile with that longing.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O the state, and greatnesse of that place
Where men are found
Only to give the first creation glory!
Those are the models of the ancient world
Left like the Roman statues to stir up
Our following hopes, the place it selfe puts on
The brow of Majestie, and flings her lustre
Like the aire newly lightned, forme, and order,
Are only there themselues, unforc't, and sound,
As they were first created to this place.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: You nobly came, but wil goe from thence base.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Twas very pretty, and a good conceite;
You have a wit good Cozen, I do joy in't,
Keep it for Court: but to my selfe againe,
When I have view'd these pieces, turn'd these eyes,
And with some taste of superstition,
Lookt on the wealth of Nature, the faire dames,
Beauties, that lights the Court, and makes it shew
Like a faire heaven, in a frosty night:
And mongst these mine, not poorest, 'tis for tongues
Of blessed Poets, such as Orpheus was,
To give their worth and praises; O deare Cozen:
You have a wife, and faire, bring her hither,
Let her not live to be the Mistris of a Farmers heir
And be confined ever to a serge,
Farre courser then my horse-cloath.
Let her have Velvets, Tiffinies, Jewels, Pearls,
A Coach, an Usher, and her two Lacquies,
And I will send my Wife to give her rules,
And reade the rudiments of Court to her.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Sir I had rather send her to Virginia
To help to propagate the English nation. Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Sirra, how slept your Mistris, and what visitants
Are to pay service?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir as I came out,
Two Counts were newly entered.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This is greatnesse,
But few such servants waite a Countrey beauty.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: They are the more to thank their modesty,
God keep my wife, and all my Issue female
From such uprisings. Enter a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What? my learned Doctor?
You will be welcome, give her health and youth
And I will give you gold. Exit Doctor.
Cozen, how savours this? is it not sweet?
And very great, tasts it not of Noblenesse?

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Faith Sir my pallat is too dull and lazie
I cannot taste it, 'tis not for my relish,
But be so still.
Since your own misery must first reclaime ye,
To which I leave you Sir,
If you will yet be happy, leave the humour
And base subjection to your Wife, be wise,
And let her know with speed you are her husband,
I shall be glad to heare it.
My horse is sent for. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Even such another countrey thing as this
Was I, such a piece of durt, so heavy,
So provident to heap up ignorance,
And be an asse: such musty cloaths wore I,
So old and threed-bare: I do yet remember
Divers young Gallants lighting at my gate,
To see my honoured wife, have offered pence,
And bid me walk their horses, such a slave
Was I in shew then: but my eyes are open'd.
Many sweet morrows to my worthy Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis well, and aptly given, as much for you,
But to my present businesse, which is moneyâ€”

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Lady I have none left.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I hope you dare not say so, nor imagin so base and lowe,
A thought: I have none left.
Are these words fitting for a man of worth,
And one of your full credite? Do you know
The place you live in? me, and what I labour
For, you? and your advancement?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes my dearest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And do you pop me off with this slight answer,
In troth I have none left? in troth you must have;
Nay stare not, 'tis most true, send speedily
To all that love you, let your people flye
Like thunder through the Citie,
And not return under five thousand crownes.
Try all, take all, let not a wealthy merchant be untempted
Or any that hath the name of money,
Take up at any use, give band, or land,
Or mighty statutes able by their strength
To tye up Sampson were he now alive,
There must be money gotten; for be perswaded,
If we fall now, or be but seen to shrinke,
Under our faire beginnings, 'tis our ruine,
And then good-night to all, (but our disgrace)
Farewell the hope of comming happinesse,
And all the aimes we levied at so long.
Are ye not mov'd at this? no sense of want,
Towards your selfe yet breeding? be old,
And common; jaded to the eyes
Of groomes, and pages, chamber-maides, and garders,
And when you have done, put your poor house in order
And hang your selfe, for such must be the end
Of him that willingly forsakes his hopes
And hath a joy to tumble to his ruine.
All that I say is certaine, if ye faile
Do not impute me with it, I am cleare.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now heaven forbid I should do wrong to you
My dearest Wife, and Madam; yet give leave
To your poore creature to unfold himselfe.
You know my debts are many more then meanes,
My bands not taken in, my friends at home
Drawn dry with these expences, my poore Tenants
More full of want then we, then what new course
Can I beget to raise those crowns by? speake,
And I shall execute.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Pray tell me true,
Have you not land in the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pardon me, I had forgot it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, you must remember it,
There is no remedy, this land must be
In Paris ere to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It shall, let me consider, some 300. acres
Will serve the turne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Twill furnish at all points,
Now you speak like your selfe, and know like him,
That meanes to be man, suspect no lesse
For the return will give ye five for one,
You shall be great to morrow, I have said it.
Farewell, and see this businesse be a-foote
With expedition. Exit Wife.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Health, all joy, and honour
Waite on my lovely wife. What? Jaques, Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir did you call?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I did so, hie the Iaques.
Downe to the Bancke, and there to some good Merchant
(Conceive me well good Iaques, and be private)
Offer 300. acres of my land:
Say it is choise, and fertile, aske upon it
Five thousand Crowns, this is the businesse
I must employ thee in, be wise and speedy.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir do not do this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Knave I must have money.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: If you have money thus, your knave must tell ye
You will not have a foote of land left, be more warie
And more friend to your selfe, this honest land
Your Worship has discarded, has been true,
And done you loyall service.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Gentle Iaques,
You have a merry wit, employ it well
About the businesse you have now in hand.
When ye come backe, enquire me in the presence,
If not, in the Tennis-Court, or at my house. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: If this vaine hold, I know where to enquire ye.
Five thousand crowns, this with good husbandry
May hold a month out, then 5000. more,
And more land a bleeding for't, as many more
And more land laid aside. God and St. Dennis
Keep honest minded young men Bachellers.
'Tis strange My Mr. should be yet so young
A puppy, that he cannot see his fall
And got so neare the sun. I'le to his Cozen
And once more tell him on't, if he faile,
Then to my mortgage, next unto my sale. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Longovile, Bewford, and the Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Gentlemen, hold on discourse a while,
I shall return with knowledge how, and where
We shall have best accesse unto my Mistris
To Tender your devotions. Exit

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Be it so:
Now to our first discourse.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I prethee peace;
Thou canst not be so bad, or make me know
Such things are living, doe not give thy selfe
So common and so idle, so open vile,
So great a wronger of thy worth, so low,
I cannot, nor I must not credite thee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Now by this light I am a Whore-master,
An open and an excellent Whore-master,
And take a speciall glory that I am so:
I thank my stars I am a Whore-master,
And such a one as dare be known and seen,
And pointed at to be a noble wencher.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Do not let all eares heare this, harke ye Sir,
I am my selfe a Whore-master, I am
Believe it Sir (In private be it spoken)
I love a Whore directly, most men are Wenchers,
And have profest the science, few men
That looks upon ye now, but Whore-masters,
Or have a full desire to be so.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: This is noble.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: It is without all question, being private,
And held as needfull as intelligence,
But being once discover'd, blown abroad,
And known to common senses, 'tis no more
Then geometrical rules in Carpenters
That only know some measure of an art,
But are not grounded: be no more deceived,
I have a conscience to reclaim you, Sir.
Mistake me not: I do not bid you leave your whore
Or lesse to love her; forbid it
I should be such a villain to my friend,
Or so unnaturall: 'twas never harbor'd here,
Learn to be secret first, then strike your Deere.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your faire instructions Monsieur I shall learn.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: And you shall have them: I desire your care.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: They are your servants.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You must not love.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I meane a Lady, there's danger
Shee hath an Usher and a Waiting-Gentlewoman,
A page, a Coach-man, these are feed, and fee'd
And yet for all that will be prating.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You understand me Sir, they will discover't,
And there is a losse of credite: table talke
Will be the end of this, or worse, then that;
Will this be worthy of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Proceed good Sir.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Next leave your City Dame;
The best of that tribe are most meerly coy,
Or most extreamely foolish, both which vices
Are no great stirrers up, unlesse in husbands
That owe this Cattle, fearing her that's coy
To be but seeming, her that's foole too forward.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This is the rarest fellow, and the soundest
I meane in knowledge, that ere wore a Codpiece,
H'as found out that will passe all Italy,
All France and England, to their shames I speake
And to the griefes of all their Gentlemen
The noble theory of luxury.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Your patience,
And I will lay before your eyes a course
That I my selfe found out, 'tis excellent,
Easy, and full of freedome.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O good Sir,
You rack me till I know it.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This it is,
When your desire is up, your blood well heated
And apt for sweet encounter, chuse the night
And with the night your wench the streets have store,
There seize upon her, get her to your chamber,
Give her a cardecew, 'tis royall payment
When ye are dull, dismisse her, no man knows
Nor she her selfe, who hath encountred her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O but their faces.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Nere talke of faces:
The night allows her equall with a Dutches,
Imagination doth all think her faire,
And great, clapt in velvet, she is so
Sir, I have tryed those, and do find it certaine
It never failes me, 'tis but twelve nights since
My last experience.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O my meiching varlet, I'le fit ye as I live.
'Tis excellent, I'le be your Scholler Sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are fairly welcome both: troth Gentlemen
You have been strangers, I could chide you for't,
And taske ye with unkindness, what's the news?
The towne was never empty of some novelty;
Servant, what's your intelligence?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Faith nothing.
I have not heard of any worth relating

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Nor I sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Then give me attention,
Monsieur Shattillion's mad.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Mad?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Mad as May-butter,
And which is more, mad for a wench.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, and full of pitty.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: All that comes neare him
He thinks are come of purpose to betray him,
Being full of strange conceite: the wench he loved
Stood very near the Crowne.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Alas good Monsieur;
A' was a proper man, and faire demean'd,
A person worthy of a better temper.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: He is strong opinion'd that the wench he loved
Remaines close prisoner by the Kings command:
Fearing her title, when the poore grieved Gentlewoman
Follows him much lamenting, and much loving
In hope to make him well, he knows her not,
Nor any else that comes to visite him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Let's walk in Gentlemen, and there discourse
His further miseries, you shall stay dinner,
In truth you must obey.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We are your servants. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Ther's no good to be done, no cure to be wrought
Upon my desperate kinsman: I'le to horse
And leave him to the fooles whip, misery.
I shall recover twenty miles this night,
My horse stands ready, I'le away with speed.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Sir, may I crave your name?

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Yes Sir you may:
My name is Cleremon.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: 'Tis wel, your faction?
What party knit you with?

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I know no parties,
Nor no factions Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then weare this crosse of white:
And where you see the like they are my friends,
Observe them well, the time is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Sir keep your crosse, I'le wear none, sure this fellow
Is much beside himselfe, grown mad.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: A word Sir;
You can pick nothing out of this, this crosse
Is nothing but a crosse, a very crosse,
Plaine without spell or witch-craft, search it,
You may suspect, and well, there's poyson in't,
Powder, or wild-fire, but 'tis nothing so.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I do beleeve you Sir, 'tis a plain crosse.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then do your worst, I care not, tell the King,
Let him know all this, as I am sure he shall;
When you have spit your venome, then will I
Stand up a faithfull, and a loyall subject,
And so God save His Grace, this is no Treason.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.p: He is March mad, farewell Monsieur. Exit Couzen.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Farewell;
I shall be here attending, 'tis my life
They aime at, there's no way to save it, well
Let 'em spread all their nets: they shall not draw me
Into any open Treason, I can see,
And can beware, I have my wits about me,
I thanke heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: There he goes,
That was the fairest hope the French Court bred,
The worthiest and the sweetest temper'd spirit,
The truest, and the valiantest, the best of judgment,
Till most unhappy I: sever'd those vertues
And turn'd his wit wild with a coy deniall,
Which heaven forgive me, and be pleas'd, O heaven
To give againe his senses: that my love
May strike off all my follies.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I Sis

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Your will with me sweete Lady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir I come.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: From the dread soueraigne King, I know it Lady,
He is a gracious Prince, long may he live,
Pertaine you to his chamber?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No indeed Sir,
That place is not for women, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Yes, I do know you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: What's my name? pray you speake.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: That's all one, I do know you and your businesse,
You are discovered Lady, I am warie,
It stands upon my life; pray excuse me,
The best man of this kingdome sent you hither,
To dive into me, have I toucht you? ha?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd Sir, I come from your love,
That sends you faire commends, and many kisses.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Alas poore soule how does she? is she living?
Keepes she her bed still?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Still Sir, She is living,
And well, and shall do so.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Are ye in counsell?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No Sir, nor any of my sex.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why so,
If you had been in counsell, you would know,
Her time to be but slender; she must die.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I do believe it Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: And suddainely,
She stands too neare a fortune.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: 'Tis so,
There is no jesting with a Princes title,
Would we had both been borne of common parents
And liv'd a private and retired life,
In homely cottage, we had then enjoyed,
Our loves, and our embraces, these are things,
That cannot tend to treasonâ€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I am wretched.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: O I pray as often for the King as any,
And with as true a hart, for's continuance,
And do moreover pray his heires may live;
And their faire issues, then as I am bound
For all the states and commons, if these prayers
Be any wayes ambitious, I submit,
And lay my head downe let 'em take it off;
You may informe against me, but withall
Remember my obedience to the crowne,
And service to the state.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Good Sir, I love yee.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then love the gratious King, and say with me

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Heaven save his grace.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This is strangeâ€”
A woman should be sent to undermine me,
And buz love into me to try my spirit;
Offer me kisses and enticing follies,
To make me open and betray my selfe;
It was a subtle and a dangerous plot,
And very soundly followed, farewell Lady,
Let me have equall hearing, and relate
I am an honest man. Heaven save the King. Exit.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'le never leave him, till by art or prayer
I have restorde his senses, If I make
Him perfect man againe, he's mine still, when
I here abjure all loves of other men. Exit

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir be perswaded, go but back,
And tell him hee's undone, say nothing else;
And you shall see how things will worke upon't.

sp.speaker: Cozen.
sp.l: Not so good Jaques, I am held an asse
A countrey foole, good to converse with durte
And eate course bread, weare the worst wooll,
Know nothing but the high way to Paris,
And wouldst thou have me bring these staynes,
And imperfections to the rising veiw
Of the right worshipfull thy worthy Master?
They must be bright and shine, their cloathes
Soft velvet and the trojan purple
Like the Arabian gums, hung like the Sun,
Their golden beames on all sides;
Such as these may come and know,
Thy Master, I am base and dare not speake unto him,
Hee's above me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If ever you did love him, or his state,
His name, his issue, or your selfe, go backe:
'Twill be an honest and a noble part
Worthy a kinsman, save 300 acres
From present execution; they have had sentence,
And cannot be repriev'd, be mercifull.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Have I not urg'd already all the reasons,
I had to draw him from his will? his ruine?
But all in vaine, no counsell will prevaile,
Has fixt himselfe, ther's no removing Jaques,
'Twil prove but breath and labour spent in vaine,
I'le to my horse, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ja..
sp.l: For Gods sake Sir,
As ever you have hope of joy turne backe;
I'le be your slave for ever, do but go,
And I will lay such faire directions to you
That if hee be not doting on his fall,
He shall recover sight, and see his danger,
And ye shall tell him of his wives abuses,
I feare, to foule against him; how she plots,
With our young Mounsiers, to milke dry her husband,
And lay it on their backs, the next her pride,
Then what his debts are, and how infinite
The curses of his tenants, this will worke
I'le pawne my life and head, he cryes away,
I'le to my house in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Come I'le go, and once more try him,
If he yeild not, so,
The next that tryes him shall be want and woe. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Sir. within.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Rise Jaques 'tis growne day,
The country life is best, where quietly
Free from the clamour of the troubled Court,
We may enjoy our own greene shadowed walkes,
And keepe a moderate diet without art.
Why did I leave my house and bring my wife,
To know the manner of this subtile place?
I would when first the lust to fame an honour,
Possest me, I had met with any evill.
But that, had I been tyed to stay at home
And earn the bread for the whole family
With my own hand happy had I been.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir this is from your wonted course at home,
When did ye there keep such inordinate hours?
Goe to bed late? start thrice? and call on me?
Would you were from this place; our Countrey sleepes,
Although they were but of that moderate length
That might maintain us in our daily worke.
Yet were they sound and sweet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I Jaques, there we dreamt not of our wives, wee lay together;
And needed not; now at length my Cozins words,
So truly ment, mixt with thy timely prayers
So often urged, to keepe me at my home,
Condemne me quite.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Twas not your fathers course:
He liv'd and dy'd in Orleance, where he had
His Vines as fruitfull as experience
(Which is the art of husbandry) could make;
He had his presses for 'em, and his wines
Were held the best, and out-sold other mens,
His corne and cattell serv'd the neighbour Townes
With plentifull provision, yet his thrift
Could misse one beast amongst the heard,
He rul'd more where he liv'd, then ever you will here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis true, why should my wife then 'gainst my good,
Perswade me to continue in this course?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why did you bring her hither at the first,
Before you warm'd her blood with new delights!
Our countrey sports could have contented her,
When you first married her; a puppet-play
Pleas'd her as well as now the tilting doth.
She thought her selfe brave in a bugle chaine,
Where Orient pearle will scarce content her now.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sure Jaques, she sees something for my good
More then I doe, she oft will talk to me
Of offices, and that she shortly hopes
By her acquaintance with the friends she hath
To get a place shall many times outway
Our great expences, and if this be soâ€”

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Think better of her words, she doth deceive you,
And only for her vaine and sensuall ends
Perswade ye thus. Let me be set to dwell
For ever naked in the barest soile
So you will dwell from hence.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I see my folly,
Packe up my stuffe, I will away this morne.
Hasteâ€” haste.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I, Now I see your Fathers honours
Trebling upon you, and the many prayers
The countrey spent for him, which almost now
Begun to turn to curses, turning backe,
And falling like a timely shower
Upon ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Goe, call up my wife.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But shall she not prevaile,
And sway you, as she oft hath done before?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not heare her, but raile on her
Till I be ten miles off.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you be forty,
'Twill not be worse Sir:

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Call her up,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I will Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why what an Asse was I that such a thing
As a wife is could rule me?
Know not I that woman was created for the man,
That her desires, nay all her thoughts should be
As his are? is my sense restor'd at length?
Now she shall know, that which she should desire,
She hath a husband that can govern her,
If her desires leades me against my will;
Are you come?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What sad unwonted course
Makes you raise me so soone, that went to bed
So late last-night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O you shall goe to bed sooner hereafter,
And be rais'd againe at thriftie hours,
In Summer-time wee'l walke
An houre after our supper, and to bed,
In winter you shall have a set at Cards,
And set your maids to worke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What do you meane?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I wil no more of your new tricks, your honours,
Your offices, and all your large preferments,
Which still you beate into my eares, hang ore me.
I'le leave behind for others, the great sway
Which I shall beare at Court: my living here
With countenance of your honoured friends
I'le be content to loose: for you speake this
Only that you may still continue here
In wanton ease: and draw me to consume
In cloaths and other things idle for shew
That which my Father got with honest thrift.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why, who hath been with you Sir,
That you talke thus out of Frame.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You make a foole of me:
You provide one to bid me forth to supper
And make me promise; then must some one or other
Invite you forth, if you have borne your selfe
Loosely to any Gentleman in my sight
At home, you ask me how I like the carriage,
Whether it were not rarely for my good,
And open'd not a way to my preferment?
Come I perceive all: talke not, we'le away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why Sir, you'le stay till the next triumph
Day be past?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I, you have kept me here triumphing
This seven yeares, and I have ridden through the streetes,
And bought embroyderd hose and foote-cloths too,
To shew a subjects zeale, I rode before
In this most gorgeous habit, and saluted
All the acquaintance I could espie
From any window, these were wayes ye told me
To raise me; I see all: make you ready straight,
And in that gowne which you came first to Town in,
Your safe-guard, cloake, and your hood sutable:
Thus on a duble gelding shall you amble,
And my man Jaques shall be set before you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But will you goe?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And shall I too?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: And you shall too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But shall I by this light?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why by this light you shall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then by this light
You have no care of your estate, and mine.
Have we been seven years venturing in a ship,
And now upon return with a faire winde
And a calme sea, full fraught with our own wishes
Laden with wealth and honour to the brim,
And shall we flye away and not receive it?
Have we been tilling, sowing, labouring
With paine and charge a long and tedious winter,
And when we see the corne above the ground,
Youthfull as is the morne and full eare
That promises to stuffe our spatious garners,
Shall we then let it rot, and never reap it?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Wife talke no more, your Retoricke comes too late,
I am inflixable; and how dere you
Adventure to direct my course of life?
Was not the husband mad to rule the wife?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis true but where the man doth misse his way,
It is the womans part to set him right;
So Fathers have a power to guide their Sonnes
In all their courses, yet you oft have seene
Poore litle children that have both their eyes
Lead their blind Fathers.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: She has a plaguy witt,
I say you'r but a little piece of man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But such a peice, as being tane away
Man cannot last: the fairest and tallest ship,
That ever saild, is by a little peice of the same
Wood, steerd right, and turnd about.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis true she sayes, her answers stand with reason.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But Sir, your Cozin put this in your head
Who is an enemie to your preferment,
Because I should not take place of his wife;
Come by this kisse thou shalt not go sweete heart.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Come, by this kisse I will goe Sweet-heart,
On with your riding stuffe; I know your tricks,
And if preferment fall ere you be ready,
'Tis welcome, else adue the Citie life.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Well Sir I will obey.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: About it then,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To please your humour I would dresse my selfe,
In the most loathsome habit you could name
Or travell any whether ore the world
If you command me, it shall neere be said
The fraylty of a woman whose weake minde,
Is often set on loose delights and shewes,
Hath drawne her husband to consume his state,
In the vaine hope of that which never fell.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: About it then, women are pleasant creatures,
When once a man begins to know himselfe.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But harke you Sir because I wilbe sure,
You shall have no excuse, no word to say
In your defence hereafter; when you see
What honours were preparde for you and me
Which you thus willingly have throwne away,
I tell you I did looke for present honour,
This morning for you, which I know had come
But if they do not come ere I am ready
(Which I will be the sooner least they should)
When I am once set in a countrey life,
Not all the power of earth shall alter me,
Not all your prayers or threats shall make me speak
The Least words to my honourable freinds
To do you any grace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not wish it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And never more hope to be honourable,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My hopes are lower.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: As I live you shall not,
You shall be so farr from the name of noble
That you shall never see a Lord againe;
You shall not see a maske, or Barriers,
Or tilting or a solemn christning,
Or a great marriage, or new fire-works,
Or any bravery; but you shall live
At home bespotted with your owne loved durt
In scurvy cloathes as you were wont to doe,
And to content you I will live so too.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis all I wish, make hast the day drawes on,
It shall be my care to see your stuffe pact up.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It shal be my care to gul you: you shal stay. Ex. Gen.
And more then so intreat me humbly too
You shall have honours presently; Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Bring hither, pen, inke, and paper.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your Master Will not stay,
Unlesse preferment come within an houre.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let him commande one of the Citie gates
In time of mutiny, or you may provide him,
To be one of the counsell for invading,
Some savage countrey to plant christian faith.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, I have it for him, call my page
Now my deare husband there it is will fit you. Exit. Maria
And when the world shall see what I have done,
Let it not move the spleene of any wife,
To make an asse of her beloved husband
Without good ground, but if they will be drawne
To any reason by you, do not gull them;
But if they grow conceited of themselves,
And be fine Gentlemen, have no mercie,
Publish them to the world, 'twill do them good
When they shall see their follies understood,
Go beare these letters to my servant,
And bid him make hast, I will dresse my selfe,
In all the journey cloathes I used before
Not to ride but to make the laughter more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is all pact up?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: All, all Sir, there is no tumbler,
Runs throw his hoop with more dexteritie
Then I aboute this businesse: tis a day
That I have long longd to see.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come where's my spurs?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here Sir, and now 'tis come.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I Jaques now
I thanke my fates, I can command my wife.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am glad to see it Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I do not love alwayes,
To be made a puppie, Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But yet me thinkes your worship does not looke,
Right like a countrey Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will, give me my tother hat.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: So, my Ierkin.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: On with it Jaques, thou and I
Will live so finely in the countrey, Jaques,
And have such pleasant walks into the woods
A mornings, and then bring whom riding rods,
And walking stavesâ€”

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And I will beare them Sir,
And skurdge-sticks for the children.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: So thou shalt,
And thou shalt do all, over see my worke folkes
And at the weekes end pay them all their wages.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I will Sir, so your worship give me mony.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Thou shalt receive all too: give me my drawers

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: They are ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And I will make thy Mistriss,
My wife, looke to her landrie and her dayry,
That we may have our linnen cleane on Sundayes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And holy dayes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I and ere we walke about the grounds
Provide our breake-fast,
Or she shall smoke, I'le have her a good huswife
She shall not make a voyage to her sisters,
But she shall live at home,
And feed her pullen fat, and see her maides
In bed before her, and locke all the doores

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why that will be a life for Kings and Queenes.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Give me my Scarfe with the great button quickly.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: 'Tis done Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Now my Mittens.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Here they are Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis well? now my great dagger.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why so; thus it should be, now my riding rod.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: There's nothing wanting Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Another, man, to sticke under my girdle.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: There it is.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: All is well.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Why now me thinks your Worship looks
Like to your selfe, a man of meanes and credit,
So did your grave and famous Ancestors,
Ride up and down to faires, and cheapen cattell.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Goe, hasten your Mistrisse, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: It shall be done. Exit Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who's that? who's that boy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I thinke it be my Master.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who, he that walkes in gray whisking his riding rod?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes Sir, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed; he is prepar'd
For his new journey; when I wink upon you
Runne out and tell the Gentleman 'tis timeâ€”
Monsieur good day.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Monsieur your Mistrisse is within, but yet not ready.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My businesse is with you Sir; 'tis reported,
I know not whether by some enemie
Maliciously that envies your great hopes,
And would be ready to sow discontents
Betwixt his Majesty and you, or truly,
Which on my faith I would be sorry for,
That you intend to leave the Court in hast.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Faith Sir within this halfe houre. Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaques within:
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Is my wife ready?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But Sir,
I needs must tell you as I am your friend,
You should have tane your journey privater
For 'tis already blaz'd about the Court.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why Sir, I hope it is no Treason, is it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir, but 'tis grown the common talk,
There's no discovery else held, and in the presence
All the Nobility and Gentry
Have nothing in their mouths but only this,
Monsieur Marine that noble Gentleman,
Is now departing hence, every mans face
Looks ghastly on his fellows, such a sadnesse
(Before this day) I nere beheld in Court,
Mens hearts begin to faile them when they heare it,
In expectation of the great event
That needs must follow it, pray heaven it be good!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why I had rather all their hearts should faile
Then I stay here untill my purse faile me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But yet you are a Subject, and beware
I charge you by the love I beare to you
How you doe venture rashly on a course
To make your soveraign jealous of your deeds
For Princes jealousies where they love most,
Are easily found, but they be hardly lost.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Come these are tricks, I smell 'em, I will goe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Have I not still profest my selfe your friend?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Yes, but you never shewd it to me yet.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But now I will, because I see you wise,
And give ye thus much light into a businesse
That came to me but now, be resolute,
Stand stifly to it that you will depart,
And presently.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why so I meane to doe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And by this light you may be what you will;
Will you be secret Sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The King does feare you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And is now in Counsell;

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: About me;

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: About you, and you be wise,
You'l finde hee's in Counsell about you?
His Councellours have told him all the truth.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What truth?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why? that which now he knows too well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: That you have followed him seven years
With a great traine: and though he have not grac't you,
Yet you have div'd into the hearts of thousands,
With liberality and noble carriage;
And if you should depart home unprefer'd
All discontented, and seditious spirits
Would flocke to you and thrust you into action:
With whose help, & your Tenants, who doth not know
(If you were so dispos'd:)
How great a part of this yet fertile peaceful realm of Fran.
You might make desolate? but when the King
Heard thisâ€”

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: what said he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nothing, but shook,
As never Christian Prince did shake before.
And to be short you may be what you will?
But be not ambitious Sir, sit downe
With moderate honours, least you make your selfe
More feard.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I know Sir what I have to doe
In mine own businesse. Enter Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Where's Monsieur Mount Marine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why there he stands, will you ought with him?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Yes: Good day Monsieur Marine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good day to you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: His Majesty doth commend himselfe,
Most kindly to you Sir, and hath by me,
Sent you this favour: kneele downe, rise a Knight.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I thank his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And he doth further request you,
Not to leave the Court so soone,
For though your former merits have been slighted,
After this time there shall no Office fall;
Worthy your spirit, as he doth confesse
There's none so great, but you shall surely have it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Do you heare, if you yield yet you are an asse.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I'le shew my service to his Majesty
In greater things then these, but for this small one
I must intreat his Highnesse to excuse me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'le beare your Knightly words unto the King,
And bring his Princely answer backe againe. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Well said, be resolute a while, I know
There is a tide of honours comming on.
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Where is this new made Knight?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Let me enfold you in my arms,
Then call you Lord, the King will have it so,
Who doth entreat your Lordship to remember
His message sent to you by Longavile.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: If ye be durty, and dare not mount aloft;
You may yield now, I know what I would do.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Peace, I will fit him; tell his Majesty
I am a Subject, and I do confesse
I serve a gracious Prince, that thus hath heapt
Honours on me without desert, but yet
As for the message, businesse urgeth me,
I must be gone, and he must pardon me,
Were he ten thousand Kings and Emperours.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I'le tell him so.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, this was like your selfe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: As he hath wrought him, 'tis the finest fellow
That ere was Christmas Lord, he carries it
So truly to the life, as though he were
One of the plot to gull himselfe. Exit Bewf.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why so, you sent the wisest and the shrewdest
Unto the King, I swear, my honoured friend
That ever any Subject sent his Liege.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nay now I know I have him on the hip,
I'le follow it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My honourable Lord,
Give me your noble hand right courteous Peer,
And from henceforth be a courtly Earl;
The King so wills, and Subjects must obey:
Only he doth desire you to consider
Of his request.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why faith your well my Lord, yield to him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yield? why 'twas my plot.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nay 'twas your wives plot.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: To get preferment by it,
And thinks he now to pop me ith mouth
But with an Earldome, Ile be one step higher.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis the finest Lord, I am afraid anon
He will stand upon't to share the Kingdome with him.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Wher's this Courtly Earle?
His Majesty commends his love unto you;
And will you but now grant to his request,
He bids you be a Duke, and chuse of whence.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why if you yield not now, you are undone,
What can you wish to have more, but the Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So please his Majesty, I would be Du. of Burgundy
Because I like the place.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I Know the King is pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Then will I stay and kisse his Highnesse hand.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: His Majesty wil be a glad man when he hears it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: But how shall we keep this from the worlds eare
That some one tell him not, he is no Duke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Wee'l think of that anon.
Why Gentlemen, is this a gracious habit for a Duke?
Each gentle body set a finger to
To pluck the clouds of this his riding weeds
From off the orient sunne of his best cloths;
I'le pluck one boot and spur off.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I another.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Ile pluck his Jerkin off.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sit down my Lord;
Both his spurs off at once good Longavile
And Bewford take that scarfe off, and that hat
Doth not become his largely sprouting fore-head.
Now set your gracious foot to this of mine,
One pluck will do it, so, off with the other.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Loe thus your servant Longavile doth pluck
The trophy of your former gentry off,
Off with his Jerkin Bewford.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Didst thou never see
A nimble footed Taylor stand so in his stockings,
Whilst some friend help to pluck his Jerkin off,
To dance a Jigg?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Here's his man Jaques come
Booted and ready still.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My Mistris stayes;
Why how now Sir? what do your Worship mean,
To plucke your grave and thrifty habit off?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My slippers, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O thou mighty Duke
Pardon this man,
That thus hath trespassed in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I pardon him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: His Graces slippers, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Foot-man, hee's a Duke:
The King hath rais'd him above all his land.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'le to his Couzen presently, and tell him so;
O what a dung-hill countrey rogue was I! Exit Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: See, see, my Mistrisse.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Let's observe their greeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Unto your will as every good wife ought,
I have turnd all my thoughts, and now am ready.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O Wife I am not worthy to kisse the least
Of all thy toes, much lesse thy thumb,
Which yet I would be bold with; all thy counsell
Hath been to me Angelicall, but mine to thee
Hath been most durty like my mind:
Deare Duchesse I must stay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What are you mad to make me
Dresse, and undresse, turne and winde me,
Because you find me plyant? said I not
The whole world should not alter me, if once
I were resolv'd? and now you call me Duchesse:
Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Loe a Knight doth kneel.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A Knight?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A Lord.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A foole.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I say doth kneele an Earle, a Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In drawers.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Without shoes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sure you are lunatick.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No honoured Duchesse
If you dare but believe your servants truth,
I know he is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: God save his Grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I aske your Graces pardon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I rise,
And here in token that all strife shall end
'Twixt thee and me, I let my drawers fall
And to thy hands I do deliver them:
Which signifies, that in all acts and speeches,
From this time forth my wife shall wear the breeches.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: An honourable composition. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Shall I beleeve thee Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir you may.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Didst thou not dreame?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I did not.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Nor imagine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Neither of both: I saw him great and mighty,
I saw the Monsieurs bow, and heard them cry
Good health and fortune to my Lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: A Duke art sure? a Duke?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am sure a Duke,
And so sure as I know my selfe for Jaques.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Yet the sun may dazell? Jaques, was it not
Some leane Commander of an angry Block-house
To keep the fleamish Eele-boats from invasion,
Or some bold Baron able to dispend
His fifty pounds a yeare, and meet the foe
Upon the Kings command in gilded canvas,
And do his deeds of worth? or was it not
Some place of gaine, as Clerk to the great Band
Of maribones, that people call the Switzers?
Men made of beufe, and sarcenet?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Is a Duke his chamber hung with Nobles like a presence?

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I am something wavering in my faith;
Would you would settle me, and sweare 'tis so,
Is he a Duke indeed?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I sweare he is.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I am satisfied, he is my Kinsman. Jaques,
And I his poor unworthy Couzen.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: True Sir.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I might have been a Duke too, I had meanes,
A wife as faire as his, and as wise as his;
And could have brookt the Court as well as his,
And laid about her for her husbands honour:
O Jaques had I ever dreamt of this,
I had prevented him.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Faith Sir it came
Above our expectation, we were wise
Only in seeking to undoe this honour,
Which shewed our dung-hill breeding and our durt.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: But tell me Iaques,
Why could we not perceive? what dull Divell
Wrought us to crosse this noble course, perswading
'Twould be his overthrow? for me a Courtier
Is he that knows all, Iaques, and does all,
'Tis as his noble Grace hath often said,
And very wisely, Jaques, we are fooles,
And understand just nothing.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I, as we were, I confesse it.
But rising with our great Master,
We shall be call'd to knowledge with our places,
'Tis nothing to be wise, not thus much there,
Ther's not the least of the billet dealers,
Nor any of the Pastry, or the Kitchin,
But have it in measure delicate.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Me thinks this greatness of the Dukes my Couzens
(I aske you mercy, Iaques, that near name
Is too familiar for me) should give promise
Of some great benefits to his attendants.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I have a suite my selfe, and it is sure,
Or I mistake my ends much.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: What is 't Iaques,
May I not crave the place?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir you shall,
'Tis to be but his Graces Secretary,
Which is my little all, and my ambition,
Till my known worth shall take me by the hand
And set me higher; how the fates may do
In this poor threed of life is yet uncertaine;
I was not born I take it for a trencher,
Nor to espouse my Mistris Dairy-maid.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: I am resolv'd my wife shall up to Court;
I'le furnish her, that is a speeding course,
And cannot chuse but breed a mighty fortune;
What a fine youth was I, to let him start,
And get the rise before me? I'le dispatch
And put my selfe in moneys.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Masse 'tis true,
And now you talke of money, Sir my businesse
For taking those Crowns must be dispatcht?
This litle plot in the Countrey lies most fit
To do his Grace such serviceable uses,
I must about it.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: Yet before you goe
Give me your hand, and bear my humble service
To the great Duke your Master, and his Duchesse,
And live your selfe in favour: say my wife
Shall there attend them shortly, so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'le see you mounted Sir.

sp.speaker: Cous.
sp.l: It may not be,
Your place is far above it, spare your selfe,
And know I am your servant, fare ye well. Exit Cousen.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir I shall rest to be commanded by you;
This place of Secretary will not content me,
I must be more and greater, let me see,
To be a Baron is no such great matter
As people take it: for say I were a Count,
I am still an under person to this Duke,
Which me thinks sounds but harshly: but a Duke?
O I am strangely taken, 'tis a Duke
Or nothing, I'le advise upont, and see
What may be done by wit and industry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It must be carried closely with a care
That no man speak unto him, or come near him
Without our private knowledge, or be made
Afore-hand to our practice:
My good husband
I shall entreat you now to stay a while,
And prove a noble coxcomb:
Gentlemen,
Your counsell and advice about this carriage.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Alas good man, I do begin to mourn
His dire massacre: what a persecution
Is pouring down upon him? sure he is sinfull.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let him be kept in 's chamber under shew
Of state and dignity, and no man sufferd
To see his noble face, or have accesse,
But we that are Conspirators.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Or else down with him into the countrey amongst his Tenants,
There he may live far longer in his greatnesse,
And play the foole in pomp amongst his fellows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, he shall play the foole in the City, and stay
I will not loose the greatnesse of this jest
That shal be given to my wit for the whole revenues.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Then thus wee'l have a guard about his person,
That no man come too neare him, and ourselves
Alwayes in company; have him into the City
To see his face swell; whilst in divers corners,
Some of our own appointing shall be ready
To cry heaven blesse your Grace, long live your Grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Servant, your counsells excellent good,
And shall be followed, twill be rarely strange
To see him stated thus, as though he went
A shroving through the City, or intended
To set up some new stake:
I shall not hold
From open laughter when I heare him crye
Come hither my sweet Dutchesse: let me kisse
Thy gracious lips: for this will be his phrases?
I feare me nothing but his legs will breake
Under his mighty weight of such a greatnesse.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Now me thinks dearest Lady you are too cruell;
His very heart will freeze in knowing this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, the man was never of such deepnesse
To make conceite his Master: Sir I'le assure ye
He will out-live twenty such pageants.
Were he but my Cozen or my Brother,
And such a desperate killer of his fortune,
In this beliefe he should dye, though it cost me
A thousand crowns a day to hold it up;
Or were I not known his wife, and so to have
An equall feeling of this ill he suffers,
He should be thus till all the boyes i'th Towne
Made sute to weare his badges in their hats,
And walke before his Grace with sticks and nose-gayes,
We married women holdâ€”

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis well, no more.
The Duke is entring, set your faces right,
And bow like Countrey prologues: here he comes.
Make roome afore, the Duke is entring.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The cheifest fortunes waite upon our Duke,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And give him all content and happinesse.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Let his great name live to the end of time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We thank you, and are pleas'd to give you notice
We shall at fitter times wait on your Loves,
Till when, be neare Us.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: 'Tis a valiant purge, and works extreamly;
'tas delivered him
Of all Right worshipfull and gentle humours,
And left his belly full of noblenesse.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It pleased the King my Master
For sundry vertues not unknown to him,
And the all-seeing state, to lend his hand
And raise me to this Emminence, how this
May seeme to other men, or stir the mindes
Of such as are my fellow Peers, I know not,
I would desire their loves in just designes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now by my faith he does well, very well:
Beshrew my heart I have not seen a better
Of a raw fellow, that before this day
Never rehearst his state: 'tis marvellous well.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Is he not Duke indeed, see how he lookes
As if his spirit were a last, or two
Above his veines, and stretcht his noble hide.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Hee's high brac't like a drum, pray God he breake not.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why let him break, ther's but a Calves-skin lost.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: May it please your Grace to see the City,
Twill be to the minds and much contentment
Of the doubtfull people.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I am determin'd so, till my returne
I leave my honoured Dutchesse to her chamber.
Be carefull of your health, I pray you be so.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Your grace shall suffer us your humble servants
To give attendance fit so great a person
Upon your body.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am pleased so.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Away good Bewford, raise a guard sufficient
To keep him from the reach of tongues, be quicke;
And do you heare, remember how the streets
Must be dispos'd with for cryes, and salutations.
Your grace determines not to see the Kingâ€”

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Not yet, I shall be ready ten dayes hence
To kisse his highnesse hand, and give him thanks,
As it is fit I should for his great bounty
Set forward Goentlemen.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Room for the Duke there. Exeunt Duke & traine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis fit he should have room to shew his mightinesse,
He swels so with his poyson,
'Tis better to reclaim ye thus, then make
A sheeps-head of you, It had been but your due;
But I have mercy Sir, and mean to reclaim you
By a directer course.
That woman is not worthy of a soule
That has the soveraign power to rule her husband,
And gives her title up, so long provided
As there be faire play, and his state not wrongd.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I would be glad to know whence this new Duke springs,
The people buz abroad, or by what title
He received his dignity, 'tis very strange
There should be such close jugling in the State,
But I am tyed to silence, yet a day
May come, and soone to perfect all these doubts.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It is the mad Shattillion by my soule
I suffer much for this poor Gentleman;
I'le speake to him, may be he yet knows me.
Monsieur Shattillion.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Can you give me reason from whence
This great Duke sprang that walkes abroad?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Even from the King himselfe.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: As you are a woman, I think you may be coverd
Yet your prayer would do no harm good woman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: God preserve him.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I say Amen, and so say all good subjects.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Lady as ever you have lov'd, or shall,
As you have hope of heaven lend your hand,
And wit to draw this poore distracted man
Under your roofe from the broad eyes of people,
And wonder of the streets.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: With all my heart;
My feeling of his griefe and losse is much.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Sir now you are come so neare the prison, wil ye
Goe in, and visit your fair Love: poore soule
She would be glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This same Duke is but
Apocryphall, there's no creation
That can stand where titles are not right.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This is another draught upon my life;
Let me examine well the words I spake.
The words I spake were, that this novell Duke
Is not ot'h true making, 'tis to me most certaine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are as right Sir as you went by line.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: And to the griefe of many thousands more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If there be any such, God comfort them.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Whose mouths may open when the time shall please;
I'me betraid, commend me to the King,
And tell him I am sound, and crave but justice;
You shall not need to have your guard upon me,
Which I am sure are plac'd for my attachment;
Lead on; I'm obedient to my bonds.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Good Sir be not displeased with us;
We are but servants to his highnesse will,
To make that good.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I doe forgive you even with my heart;
Shall I entreat a favour?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: To see my love before that fatall stroake,
And publish to the world my christian death,
And true obedience to the Crown of France.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I hope it shall not need Sir, for there is mercy
As well as justice in his Royall heart. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Every man take his corner, here am I,
You there, and you in that place, so be perfect,
Have a great care your cryes be loud; and faces
Full of dejected feare and humblenesse.
He comes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Fye how these streets are charg'd and swoll'd
With these same rascally people? give more room,
Or I shall have occasion to distribute
A martial almes amongst you; as I am a Gentleman
I have not seen such rude disorder,
They follow him like a prize, there's no true gaper
Like to your Citizen, he will be sure
The beares shall not passe by his door in peace,
But he and all his family will follow.
Roome there afore? Sound?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Give roome, and keep your places
And you may see enough; keep your places.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: These people are too far unmanner'd, thus
To stop your Graces way with multitudes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Rebuke them not good Monsieur 'tis their loves
Which I will answer, if it please my stars
To spare me life and health.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Blesse your Grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Now heaven preserve your happy days:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thank you too.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: Now heaven save your Grace;

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thanke you all.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: On there before.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Stand Gentlemen, stay yet a while,
For I am minded to impart my love
To these good people, and my friends
Whose love and prayers for my greatnesse,
Are equall in abundance, note me well,
And with my words; my heart? for as the treeâ€”

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Your Grace had best beware, 'twil be inform'd
Your greatnesse with the people.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I had more
My honest and ingenious people.â€” But
The weight of businesse hath prevented me.
I am call'd from you: but this tree I spake of
Shall bring forth fruit I hope to your content,
And so I share my bowels amongst you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A noble Duke, a very noble Duke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Afore there Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You'r faithfully met good Monsieur Mount Marine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Be advis'd, the time is alter'd.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Is he not the same man he was afore?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Still the same man to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have received mighty grace, be thankfull.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Let me not dye in ignorance;

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You shall not.
Then know the King out of his loue hath pleased
To stile him Duke of Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: O great Duke,
Thus low, I plead for pardon, and desire
To be enrol'd amongst your poorest slaves.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sir you have mercy, and withall my hand,
From henceforth let me call you one of mine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Make room afore there, and dismisse the people.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Every man to his house in peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: Peop.
sp.l: Now heaven preserve the Duke, heaven blesse the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This letter came this morn from my Cozen
To the great Lady, high and mighty Duchesse
Of Burgundy, be these delivered O,
For a stronger lace to keep my breath
That I may laugh the nine dayes till the wonder
Fall to an ebb: the high and mighty Duchesse?
The high and mighty God? what a stile is this?
Methinks it goes like a Duchy lope-man,
A ladder of 100. rounds will faile
To reach the top on't, well my Gentle Cozen
I know by these contents your itch of honour;
You must to the Court, you say, and very shortly:
You shall be welcome; and if your wife have wit
I'le put her in a thriving course, if not
Her own sin on her owne head, not a blot
Shall staine my reputation, only this
I must for healths sake sometimes
Make an asse of the tame moyle my husband;
'Twill do him good, and give him fresher brains,
Me fresher blood.
Now for the noble Duke, I heare him comming.
Your Grace is well return'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As well as may be:
Never in younger health, never more able:
I meane to be your bed-fellow this night,
Let me have good encounter.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Blesse me heaven
What a hot meat this greatnesse is?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: It may be so,
For I'le be sworn he hath not got a snap
This two months on my knowledge, or her woman
Is damd for swearing it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thank you Gentlemen for your attendance
And also your great paines, pray know my lodgings
Better and oftner, do so Gentlemen.
Now by my honour, as I am a Prince,
I speake sincerely, know my lodgings better,
And be not strangers, I shall see your service
And your deservings, when you least expect.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We humbly thank your Grace for this great favor.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your Grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be ready for the Countrey,
And let my Tenants know the Kings great love:
Say I would see them, but the waight at Court
Lyes heavy on my shoulders: let them know
I do expect their duties in attendance
Against the next feast, wait for my comming
To take up post, and be full of speed. Exit Jaques.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I would desire your Graceâ€”

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You shall desire, and have your
Full desire, sweet Duchesse speak.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To have some conference with a Gentleman
That seems not altogether void of reason?
He talks of titles, and things neare the Crown,
And knowing none so fit as your good Grace,
To give the difference in such points of Stateâ€”

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is he? If he be noble, or have any part
That's worthy our converse, We do accept him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I can assure your Grace his straine is noble,
But he's very subtle.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let him be so.
Let him have all the braines, I shall demonstrate
How this most Christian Crown of France can beare
No other shew of title then the Kings.
I will goe in and meditate for halfe an houre,
And then be ready for him presently,
I will convert him quickly or confound him.

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.l: Is mad Shattillion here?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Is here, and's Lady,
I prethee servant fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, what do you meane to put him to?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To chat with the mad lad my husband;
'Twill be brave to heare them speake, babl,
Stare, and prate.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: But what shall be the end of all this, Lady?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Leave that to me, now for the grand dispute,
For see here comes Shattillion: as I live me thinks
All France should beare part of his griefes.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I le fetch my Lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Where am I now, or whether will you lead me?
To my death? I crave my priviledge,
I must not dye but by just course of law.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: His Majesty hath sent by me your pardon,
He meant not you should dye; but would intreate you
To lay the full state of your Title open,
Unto a grave and noble Gentleman.
The Duke of Burgundy who here doth come,
Who either by his wisedome will confute you,
Or else informe and satisfie the King.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: May 't please your grace, this is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this he that chops logicke with my liege?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: dee mocke me? you are great, the time will come
When you shall be as much contemned as I,
Where are the ancient complements of France,
That upstarts brave the Princes of the bloud?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your title Sir, in short.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: He must Sir,
Be a better states man then your selfe, that can
Trip me in any thing, I will not speake
Before these witnesses.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Depart the roome, for none shall stay,
No not my dearest Dutches.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wee'le stand behind the Arras & heare all. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In that chaire take your place, I in this,
Discourse your title now.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Sir you shall know,
My loves true title, mine by marriage,
Setting aside the first race of French Kings
Which will not here concerne us, as Pharamond,
With Clodian, Meron, and Chilperik,
And to come downe unto the second race,
Which we will likewise slipâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But take me with you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I pray you give me leave, of Martell Charles,
The Father of King Pippin, who was, Sir,
To Charles the great and famous Charlemaine.
And to come to the third race of French Kings,
Which will not be great pertinent in this cause,
Betwixt the King and me, of which you know
HVGH CAPET was the first,
Next his Sonne Robert, Henry then, and Phillip
With Lewis, and his Sonne a Lewis too,
And of that name the seventy, but all this
Springs from a female as it shall appeare.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now give me leave, I grant you this your title
At the first sight carryes some shew of truth;
But if ye weigh it well ye shall finde light.
Is not his Majestie possest in peace,
And justice executed in his name,
And can you thinke the most Christian King
Would do this if he saw not reason for it?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But had not the tenth Lewis a sole daughter?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But answer me directly.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is a most seditious question.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Is this your justice?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I stand for my King.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Was ever heire apparant thus abus'd?
I'le have your head for this.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, do your worst.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Will no one stir to apprehend this traytor?
A guard about my person will? none come?
Must my owne royall hands performe the deede?
Then thus I do arrest you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Treason, help.

div.stage: Enter Wife, Long, and Bew. and Servant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Help, help, my Lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Help thy Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Forbeare his graces person.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Forbeare you to touch him that,
Your heire apparant weds,
But by this hand I will have all your heads. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How doth your grace?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why? well.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How do you finde his title?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis a dangerous one,
As can come by a female.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I 't is true,
But the law Salicke, cuts him off from all.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace how stands his title?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Pew, nothing, the law Shallicke cuts him off from all

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My gracious husband you must now prepare,
In all your graces pomp to entertaine
Your cozen, who is now a convertite,
And followes here, this night he will be here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be ready all in hast, I do intend,
To shew before my cozens wondring face Exeunt omnes.
The greatnesse of my pomp, and of my place.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Sirra is all things carried to the Taylor,
The measure and the fashion of the gowne
With the best trim?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes Sir & 'twill be ready within this two dayes.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: For my selfe I care not,
I have a suite or two of ancient velvet;
Which with some small correcting and addition
May steale into the presence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would my Gowne were ready husband, I'le lay my life,
To make you something ere to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: It must not bee
Before we see the Duke, and have advice,
How to behave ourselves: lets in the while,
And keep our selves from knowledge till time shall call us

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I much admire the fierce masculine spirit,
Of this dread Amazon.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This following night I'le have a wench in solace.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir, I heare you,
And will be with you if I live, no more.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My Lady would intreate your presence Gentlman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: We will obey your Lady, she is worthy.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You light alone, a word, or two.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your will Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Harke in your eare, wilt thou be maried? speake, wilt thou marry?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Maried? to whom Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: To a proper fellow, landed, and able bodied,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why do you flout me Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I sweare I do not, I love thee for thy Ladies sake, be free,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If I could meet such matches as you speake of,
I were a very child to loose my time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What saiest thou to Mounsier Bewford.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir I say hee's a proper Gentleman, and far
Above my meanes to looke at.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Dost thou like him?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and ever did.

sp.speaker: Long
sp.l: He is thine owne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are too greate in promises.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Be rul'd and follow my advice, he shall be thine

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would you would make it good Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Do but thus,
Get thee a cushion underneath thy cloathes,
And leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'le be your scholler,
I cannot loose much by the venture sure.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thou wilt loose a prettie maiden head, my rogue,
Or I am much o'th bow hand, you'le remember
If all this take effect, who did it for you,
And what I may deserve for such a kindnesse.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yours Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Save ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Save the King.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I pray you Sir, which is the nearest way?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Save the King, this is the nearest way.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Which is the nearest way to the post house?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: God save the King and his post.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I pray Sir direct me to the house;

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Heaven save the King, you cannot catch me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do not understand you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: You do not, I say you cannot catch me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not catch you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No Sir, nor can the King,
With all his stratagems, and his forced tricks,
Although he put his nobles in disguise;
Never so oft to sift into my words,
By course of law, lay hold upon my life.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It is businesse that my Lord the Duke
Is by the King imployed in, and he thinks
I am acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I shall not need to ripp the cause up,
From the first to you,
But if his Majesty had suffered me
To marry her, though she be after him,
The right heire generall to the Crowne of France.
I would not have convayed her into Spaine,
As it was thought, nor would I ere have joyn'd,
With the reformed Churches to make them,
Stand for my cause.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do not thinke you would.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir,
And since I see you are a favorer
Of vertues, kept in bondage;
Tell directly to my soveraigne King,
For so I will acknowledge him for ever,
How you have found my staid affections
Setled for peace, and for the present state.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And good Sir tell him further this,
That notwithstanding all suggestions
Brought to him against me and all his suspitions,
Which are innumerall to my treasons,
If he will warrant me but publique tryall,
I'le freely yeild my selfe into his hands;
Can he have more then this?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No by my troth.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I would his Majesty would heare but reason,
As well as you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But Sir you do mistake me,
For I never saw the King
In all my life but once, therefore good Sir,
May it please you to shew me which is the post house.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I cry you mercie Sir, then you'r my freind.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And such men are very rare with me,
The post house is hard by, farewell;

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, I must ride hard to night,
And it is darke already.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am cruell to send this man directly to his death
That is my freind, and I might easily save him,
He shall not dye, come backe my freind, come backe.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: do you not know?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And do you gather nothing by my face?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Vertue is ever innocent,
La not the fault on me, I greive for you,
And wish that all my teares might win your safety.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Alas good freind you are undone,
The more ill fortune, mine to be the meanes
Of your sad overthrow: you know not me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No truely Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would you had never seene me,
I am a man pursu'd by the whole state
And sure some one hath seene me talke with you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes divers Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why then your head is gon.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'le out of towne.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would it were soone enough,
Stay if you love your life, or else you are taken.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'le venture deeply for him,
Rather then to cast away an innocent,
Take courage friend, I will preserve thy life,
With hazard of mine owne.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: This night thou shalt be lodg'd within my doores,
Which shall be all lookt fast, and in the morne
I'le so provide, you shall have free accesse,
To the Sea side and so be shipt away,
Ere any know it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Good Sir suddainly I am afraide to dye.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Then follow me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: This way he went, and there's the house I hope,
His better Angell hath directed him,
To leave the wandring streetes, poore Gentleman.
Would I were able with as free a hart,
To set his soule right, as I am to grieue,
The ruine of his fame, which God forgive me;
Sir if you be within, I pray Sir speake to me.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am within and will be, what are you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A friend.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: No Sir you must pardon me,
I am acquainted with none such: be speedy,
Friend there is no other remedy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A word Sir I say I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: You cannot scape by any other meanes,
Be not feareful, God save the King,
What's your businesse Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: To speake with you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Speake out then?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Shall I not come up?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thou shalt not: flye if thou beest thin own friend,
There lyes the sute and all the furniture
Belonging to the head, on with it friend.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir do you heare?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I do, God blesse the King,
It was a habit I had laid aside,
For my owne person if the state had forced me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Good Sir unlocke your dore.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Be full of speede, I see some 20 Musketeeres in ambush,
What ere thou art, know I am here and will be,
Seest thou this bloody sword that cryes revenge?
Shake not my friend, through millions of these foes
I'le be thy guard and set thee safe aboard.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Dare you not trust me Sir?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: My good before me,
And my alleagance to the King I tell thee
Captaine (for so I guesse thee by thy armes)
And the loose flancks of halberdeeres about thee,
Thou art too weake and foolish to attempt me.
If you be ready follow me, and harke you
Upon your life speake to no living wight,
Except my selfe.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Monsieur Shattillion?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thou shalt not call agen; thus with my sword,
And the strong faith I beare unto the King;
Whom God preserve, I will descend my chamber,
And cut thy throate, I sweare I'le cut thy throate,
Steale after me and live.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I will not stay.
